Series of Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 (Pd/CZA) with different pore structures and lanthanum modified Pd/La-Al2O3 (Pd/La-A) were prepared via coprecipitation or hydrothermal method. The obtained catalysts were subjected to TWC activity evaluation, thermal stability tests as well as systematic characterizations including TEM, BET, Rietveld XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, O2-TPSR, and in situ DRIFTS. Results show that the TWC catalytic performance of Pd/Al2O3 catalyst can be obviously improved by CeO2-ZrO2 modification compared to La2O3 modification, due to the strong interaction between PdOx species and CeO2-ZrO2 support. The excellent thermal stability of Pd/CZA-2 catalyst is related to its different microstructure compared to Pd/CZA-1, because the abundant dissociated Zr4+ due to phase separation in Pd/CZA-2 could hinder the θ-Al2O3 to α-Al2O3 phase transition and retain small-sized PdOx species with excellent reoxidation ability. Besides, DRIFTS studies reveal clear structure-activity correlations between the adsorbed reaction intermediates and TWC catalytic performance, i.e. The formation of NO-Pd0 species on fresh Pd/CZA-1 is beneficial for NO conversion, while the rapid adsorption/decomposition of HC and carbonate species on Pd/CZA also contributes to better HC/CO oxidation. Nevertheless, the active sites poisoning by HC strong adsorption along with temperature-stable nitrate species on Pd/La-A cost its inferior catalytic behaviour regardless of thermal ageing. Graphical abstract Figure caption: The excellent thermal stability of Pd/CZA is related to its microstructure, as dissociated Zr4+ due to phase separation could hinder α-Al2O3 phase transition and retain small-sized PdOx species with excellent reoxidation ability. DRIFTS studies reveal clear correlations between the adsorbed reaction intermediates and TWC catalytic performance. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Three-way catalysts Palladium CeO2-ZrO2 Al2O3 Lanthanum Thermal stability 1 Introduction With the rocketing development of modern transportation and automobile industry, air pollution caused by automobile exhaust becomes major threats to both environment and human health. Three-way catalysts (TWC) can simultaneously eliminate CO, HC and NOx from gasoline engine emissions, and have been widely applied as the most efficient technology to achieve ultra-low automobiles emission [1]. Modern commercial TWCs system generally consists of noble metals (Pt, Pd, Rh), γ-Al2O3 and CeO2-ZrO2 based composite oxides. Palladium (Pd) is commonly used as a preferred noble metal element in TWCs due to its high activity for the oxidation of hydrocarbons and CO [2,3]. γ-Al2O3 is one of the typical supporting materials due to its large specific areas and highly porous structure [4]. While CeO2-ZrO2 mixed oxides owns the unique oxygen storage/release properties under variable exhaust atmospheres and have become the primary OSC material in TWCs [5–7]. The increasingly stringent exhaust regulations in recent years have pushed forward the demand for developing close coupled TWCs, where the TWC convertor is installed in close proximity to the engine's exhaust ports or even within the exhaust manifold. Such close-coupled TWCs often experience high temperatures up to 900∼1000°C which raises new challenge to the extremely high thermal stability of the TWC catalysts. γ-Al2O3 is prone to phase change and sintering, and various doping elements such as Ba, La, Zr, Sr etc. have been introduced to Pd/Al2O3 system to improve its thermal stability [8,9]. Among them, lanthanum is proved to be superior promoter to improve the textural thermal stability of alumina [10]. For example, Li et al. reported that Pd/La-Al2O3 reveals a higher propane oxidation activity than pure Pd/Al2O3 catalyst after high-temperature ageing [11]. CeO2-ZrO2 mixed oxides have also been reported effective in enhancing the thermal stability of γ-Al2O3 support. TOYOTA company proposed the “inhibitor mechanism” for CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 system, attributing thermal stability improvement to the formation of barrier interlayer between CeO2-ZrO2 and Al2O3 particles, which inhibits Al2O3 sintering and agglomeration at high temperatures [12]. Wu et al. reported that the phase transition temperature from γ-Al2O3 to α-Al2O3 increased to 1222 °C even by physically mixed Al2O3 with CeO2-ZrO2 [13]. Our previous studies show that CeO2-ZrO2 modified Al2O3 (CZA) can not only improve its thermal stability, but also achieved outstanding three-way catalytic performance even under an air-fuel ratio λ > 1 (lean burn) working conditions. However, the intrinsic micro-structural factors for the improved thermal stability of CZA system as well as their change process during thermal ageing still remain unclear, which is definitely worthy of in-depth study to provide guidance to the design of highly efficient catalysts. On the other hand, the physicochemical properties of noble metal such as dispersion, particle size, chemical valent state etc. also undergoes significantly change during thermal ageing. Various studies have reported the catalysts deactivation during ageing mainly relates to sintering, which results in severe decreased metal dispersion and aggregated large particles. It has also been reported that the encapsulation of Pd particles by the structural collapse of CeO2 support or the migration Pd species from Al2O3 support to the CeO2 happens in the Pd/CeO2/Al2O3 catalysts during thermal ageing. Besides, the interaction between precious metals and supports plays a non-negligible role in determined catalysts activity and stability. Colussi et al. reported the formation of nano faceted Pd-O-Ce sites in Pd/CeO2 catalysts, contributing to higher CH4 oxidation activity by stabilizing Pd in highly dispersed state [14]. Murthy et al. reported that the Pd nanoparticles in CeO2-Pd/SBA-15 catalyst exhibits high thermal stability due to the formation of a Pd-O-Ce bond [15]. Deng et al. reported that Pd-O-Ce bond improves the performance of converting C3H8 and NO on Pd-only three-way catalysts [16]. Our previous study also observed similar stabilizing effect against Pd sintering on Pd/CeO2-ZrO2. Considering all these complicated factors, the evolution of Pd species in Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 during thermal ageing and how it affects catalytic behavior as well as reaction intermediates/procedures requires more research attentions. In this work, Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 and Pd/La-Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized and further characterized by various methods including by various methods including TEM, BET, Rietveld XRD, XPS, H2-TPR and O2-TPSR. The TWC catalytic evaluation along with in situ DRIFTS was also conducted. The scope of this paper is: (i) to investigate the effect of CeO2-ZrO2 modification on TWC catalytic performance, textural/surface chemical properties, redox behavior as well as precious metal stability; (ii) to verify the catalysts microstructure change and reaction intermediates evolution during high temperature thermal ageing (iii) to gain new insights into structure-activity correlations induced by CeO2-ZrO2 modification for TWC applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 mixed oxide with different pore structure (denoted as CZA-1 and CZA-2, respectively) were prepared via coprecipitation or hydrothermal method. The molar ratio of Ce to Zr is kept at 4:1, while the mass ratio of CeO2-ZrO2 to Al2O3 is 1:1 in all the CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 mixed oxides. For CZA-1, Ce(NO3)2, ZrO(NO3)2 and Al(NO3)3 were first dissolved in de-ionized water, and then aqueous solution of NH3•H2O (1.5 mol/L) and (NH3)2CO3 (1.5 mol/L) was added dropwise into the nitrates solution under continuous stirring for 30 min until pH reached 9.0. The obtained suspension was aged at 80 °C for 12 h and was centrifuged and washed alternately by de-ionized water and ethanol. The washed precipitate was dried at 100 °C overnight and calcined in air at 900 °C for 4 h to obtain CZA-1 mixed oxide support. For CZA-2, Ce(NO3)2, ZrO(NO3)2 and Al(NO3)3 were first dissolved in de-ionized water along with surfactant F127 (2.25 g) and stirred for 3 h. Then, NH3•H2O (1.5 mol/L) and (NH3)2CO3 (1.5 mol/L) were added dropwise into the above solution under continuous stirring for 4 h. The obtained emulsion was then transferred to a 500 mL reaction autoclave for 12 h hydrothermal treatment at 120 °C, followed by 24 h ageing. The obtained suspension was centrifuged, washed alternately by de-ionized water/ethanol and dried at 60 °C overnight. Finally, the dried solid was calcined in air at 900 °C for 4 h to obtain CZA-2 mixed oxide support. La modified γ-Al2O3 (denoted as La-A) was also prepared for comparison using industrial product purchased from Zhejiang Da-Feng Automobile Technology CO. Ltd. The purchased powders were grinded and subjected to same calcination procedure (in air at 900 °C for 4 h) to obtain La-A support material. The corresponding supported Pd-only catalysts with 0.5 wt.% Pd loading were prepared by conventional impregnation method using Pd(NO3)2 as metal precursor. Quantitative amount of Pd(NO3)2 solution was added to the above CZA-1, CZA-2 and La-A supports along with deionized water in order to keep the solid content around 30%. The obtained mixture was stirred for 12 h and then dried (water bath at 65 °C first and transferred to the oven at 120 °C for 2 h) The dried solids were calcined in air at 500 °C for 4 h to obtained fresh Pd supported catalysts (denoted as Pd/CZA-1, Pd/CZA-2 and Pd/La-A, respectively). The aged Pd supported catalysts were also prepared by calcining fresh catalysts in muffle furnace at 1100 °C for 10 h and were designated as Pd/CZA1-a, Pd/CZA2-a and Pd/La-A-a. All the above catalysts were pellet-pressed and sieved to 40–60 mesh before further tests. 2.2 Three-way catalytic performance tests The three-way catalytic performance tests were evaluated in a self-built fixed-bed reactor. 0.2 mL catalysts were loaded and the reaction gas mixture consisted of C3H6 (670 ppm), C3H8 (330 ppm), CO (6500 ppm), NO (1000 ppm), NO2 (300 ppm), O2 with Ar as balancing gas. The reaction gas was introduced at a GHSV of 43 000 h−1 and the outlet gas was analyzed using a Bruker EQ55 FTIR spectrometer equipped with a multiple reflection gas cell (cell volume 1.33 L, path length 10.0 m). Each spectrum was collected 35 min after changing the reaction condition. The catalyst operation window was also evaluated under different air-to-fuel ratio λ values at 400 °C by adjusting oxygen concentration in the inlet reaction gas. λ was defined as [2υO2 + υNO + 2υNO2]/ [υCO + 9υC3H6 + 10υC3H8], while υ is the gas volume concentration). 2.3 Catalyst characterization techniques Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded using a TECNAI G220 apparatus operating at 200 kV. Samples were first suspended in ethanol and deposited onto a copper grid with carbon film. Specific surface areas and pore structure were tested by N2 isothermal adsorption using a Micromeritics TriStar II 3020. The samples were firstly pretreated under vacuum (< 10−5 Torr) at 200 °C for 4 h before testing. The specific surface area was calculated with the Barrett-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, while pore volume and distribution were determined with the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a Bruker D8 advanced X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The X-ray tube operated at 40 mA and 40 kV and the diffractograms were recorded in the scan range of 10−140° (2θ) with scanning rate at 1º/min. The step size is 0.02°. Maud program was used to perform the Rietveld refinement. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Thermo Escalab 250Xi system employed with Al Kα radiation at 15 kW with 12 mA current. The binding energies were calibrated using the C 1s peak at 248.6 eV. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted on a GC-1690 gas chromatograph equipped with a TCD detector. 50 mg catalyst was pre-treated in N2 flow (30 mL/min) at 200 °C for 30 min and then cooled to approximately −100 °C using liquid nitrogen-ethanol mixture. After cooling down, 5% H2/Ar (40 mL/min) were introduced till the baseline was stable. The H2-TPR profile was collected by ramping temperature with heating rate of 10 °C min−1. O2 temperature-programmed surface reaction (O2-TPSR) was conducted on a GC-1690 gas chromatograph with a TCD detector equipped. 100 mg catalyst was pre-treated in N2 flow (40 mL/min) at 500 °C for 0.5 h and then cooled to room temperature. Later, a 2% O2/He (40 mL/min) flow was applied and the catalyst was heated to 1100 °C with a rate of 20 °C min−1 after the baseline was stable. When the temperature reached 1100 °C, the catalyst was cooled down to 300 °C with the same rate, which was 20 °C min−1. The in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (In situ DRIFTS) was performed using a Nicolet 6700 FTIR equipped with mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector. Spectrum resolution of 4 cm−1 and an accumulation of 32 scans were applied in the DRIFTS tests. 100 mg catalyst was firstly pretreated in 10 mL/min Ar at 450 °C for 0.5 h and then cooled down to room temperature. The background spectra were collected at different temperature before injecting the reaction gases (same gas mixture as the catalytic activity test). DRIFTS spectra were collected by raising of temperature from 30 °C to 400 °C with an interval of 20 °C. CO chemisorption DRIFTS (CO IR) tests were also conducted on the same Nicolet 6700 FTIR. 100 mg catalyst was pre-reduced in pure H2 for 0.5 h under 350 ℃ and then purged by Ar for 0.5 h. After cooling down to room temperature, 0.65% CO/Ar mixed gas was introduced into the cell until CO adsorption was saturated, and the CO IR spectra were collecting by accumulating 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Evaluation of three-way catalytic performance Fig. 1 shows the light-off curves (pollutants conversion vs reaction temperature) of HC, CO, NO and NO2 at stoichiometric point (λ = 1) over the both the fresh and aged catalysts. For the fresh Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 catalysts, Pd/CZA-1 exhibits relatively better activity towards HC, CO and NO2 conversion, while Pd/CZA-2 presents more efficient NO reduction performance. After calcining at 1100 °C for 10 h, all the catalysts suffer obvious activity deterioration possibly due to sintering phenomena induced by thermal ageing. Comparing to the fresh samples, the ΔT90% value for HC and NO conversion (temperature difference between fresh and aged sample when conversion rate reaches 90%) of Pd/CZA2-a is much smaller than that of Pd/CZA1-a, demonstrating its excellent thermal stability. For the Pd/La-Al2O3 catalyst, although the aged Pd/La-A-a also shows small ΔT90% value, the fresh Pd/La-A presents terribly poor activity towards all the four pollutants, especially its NO conversion could not reach 90% even at high temperature. The operational windows of all the prepared catalysts were also evaluated by applying different air/fuel ratios (λ = 0.90, 0.92, 0.95, 0.98, 1.0, 1.04, 1.07, 1.1 and 1.15, respectively) at 400 °C. As shown in Fig. 2 , for both the fresh Pd/CZA-1 and Pd/CZA-2 catalysts, HC can be completely eliminated over the entire operational window range. CO conversion decreases with lower λ values under oxygen-lean conditions (λ < 1) but increases up to 100% under oxygen-rich conditions (λ > 1). While NOx conversion stays around 100% under oxygen-lean conditions but drops rapidly when λ > 1. Thermal ageing does not bring serious affection on the operation window ranges of Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 catalysts, and Pd/CZA-1 possesses wider operation window ranges than Pd/CZA-2 whether it is before or after ageing. For Pd/La-Al2O3 catalysts, due to the lack of oxygen storage/release ability, no clear operation window can be observed in either fresh Pd/La-A or aged Pd/La-A-a, as HC and NOx conversions continue to drop with higher λ values while CO conversion increases on the contrary. Thermal ageing brings clear activity deterioration to Pd/La-A-a catalyst for HC and NOx destruction, but CO conversion remains similar, which can be explained as the easy oxidation of CO at high temperature of 400 °C even over aged Pd/La-A-a catalyst. 3.2 Morphological, textural, and structural properties 3.2.1 Morphologies observation by TEM TEM photos were recorded to present direct observations regarding the morphologies of the prepared catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3 , Pd/CZA-1 prepared via coprecipitation presents as disordered amorphous particles; Pd/CZA-2 prepared via hydrothermal method consists of rod-shape particle co-existing with disordered spheroidal particles, while Pd/La-A is dominated by clavate Al2O3 particles [4]. No obvious Pd species can be identified due to low Pd loading. After 1100 °C high temperature ageing, only highly agglomerated bulk morphologies can be seen in all the catalysts, indicating severe sintering during thermal ageing. 3.2.2 Pore structure and specific surface areas by N2 physisorption Proper pore structure and high specific surface areas are very important for gas-solid heterogeneous catalytic reaction with high GHSV working conditions. Therefore, specific surface areas and pore structure were analyzed by N2 physisorption. Fig. 4 shows the BJH pore-size distribution of both the fresh and aged catalysts and Table 1 summaries the textural properties data. All the fresh Pd/CZA-1, Pd/CZA-2 and Pd/La-A exhibit typical mesoporous structures, with pore diameter follows the order of Pd/CZA-2 > Pd/La-A > Pd/CZA-1. Pd/La-A possesses the largest specific surface area, followed by Pd/CZA-1, while Pd/CZA-2 shows the smallest SBET. After high-temperature aging, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreases along with the pore volume, while the average pore diameter increases, which can be caused by severe sintering. The loss of specific surface area (ΔSBET) before and after ageing is also calculated and it also follows the order as Pd/CZA-1 > Pd/La-A > Pd/CZA-2. It's worth noticing that pore volume decrement of Pd/CZA-2 (ΔV = 4.0%) is much smaller than that of Pd/CZA-1 (ΔV = 27.3%) and Pd/La-A (ΔV = 25.3%), suggesting the outstanding thermal stability, which is also consistent with the catalytic activity results. Fig. 5 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of both fresh and aged catalysts. All the samples display type IV curves according to the IUPAC classifications, further evidencing the formation of mesoporous pores [17]. Pd/CZA-1 and Pd/CZA-2 present type H1 hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of cylindrical pores [18,19], while Pd/La-A shows type H3 hysteresis loop with a larger adsorption at high-pressure end, suggesting inhomogeneous slit-shaped pores [20]. After high temperature ageing, the hysteresis loop of Pd/CZA2-a and Pd/La-A-a remain unchanged. On the contrary, the hysteresis loop of Pd/CZA1-a changes to type H1 with relatively small adsorption amount at high-pressure end (unlike that of Pd/La-A), which can be related to the formation of homogeneous slit-shaped pores. Such transformation of pore structures during ageing can also reflect the catalysts’ thermal stability at certain degree, i.e., the Pd/CZA-1 sample gives relatively weak thermal stability compared to Pd/CZA-2 and Pd/La-A. 3.2.3 Structural analyses by XRD and Rietveld XRD XRD analyses were performed to characterize the crystalline structure of all the prepared catalysts, and the record XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 6 . No diffraction peaks assigning to PdOx phase are detected over all the samples tested. For Pd/CZA-1 and Pd/CZA-2 catalysts, major diffraction peaks assigning to the cubic fluorite CeO2 phase and γ-Al2O3 phase can be identified. Weak diffraction peak of ZrO2 appears in Pd/CZA-2, indicating slight phase separation between CeO2 and ZrO2 exists in the Pd/CZA-2 catalyst, unlike the formation CeO2-ZrO2 solid solution in the Pd/CZA-1 catalyst. Pd/La-A catalyst mainly shows typical diffraction pattern of γ-Al2O3 phase. After high temperature ageing, all the characteristics diffraction peaks become sharper, which can be related to crystallin particle sintering. For Pd/CZA1-a sample, evident diffraction peak of α-Al2O3 phase appears, suggesting phase transition of γ-Al2O3 happens during ageing. Meanwhile, more severe phase separation can be verified in Pd/CZA1-a compared to Pd/CZA2-a, which once again demonstrates the relatively weak thermal stability of Pd/CZA-1. Rietveld refinement was also performed on Pd/CZA-1 and Pd/CZA-2 using Maud software to derive more information about the microstructure evolutions before and after thermal ageing. The refinement patterns are shown in Fig. 7 and the corresponding structural parameters are given in Table 2 . Firstly, γ-Al2O3 belonging to Fd-3 m group can be detected on both samples. For the fresh Pd/CZA-1, uniformed Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 solid solution is identified, which exhibits tetragonal phase structure belonging to P42/nmc space group with c/a ratio larger than 1 [21]. According to previous studies, when CeO2 content in the CeO2-ZrO2 solid solution falls between the range of 40 to 65%, the tetragonal phase structure tends to exist in a metastable t’ phase (quasi–tetragonal) due to diffusion-less transformation. For the fresh Pd/CZA-2, the refinement results show that instead of forming uniformed CeO2-ZrO2 solid solutions, cubic CeO2 phase co-exists with tetragonal ZrO2 phase. Such lack of CeO2-ZrO2 solid solutions formation would result in less oxygen vacancies in the Pd/CZA-2 lattice and causes inferior oxygen storage and release ability, which might be one of the reasons explaining the narrower operation windows of Pd/CZA-2. Moreover, by comparing the crystalline sizes, we can that although the γ-Al2O3 crystalline size in Pd/CZA-1 is slightly larger than that of Pd/CZA-2, the crystalline size of Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 solid solution in Pd/CZA-1 is much smaller than CeO2 in the Pd/CZA-2, which might explain why Pd/CZA-1 shows larger specific surface areas. After high temperature ageing, for Pd/CZA1-a sample, the quasi-tetragonal phase Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 transforms into cubic phase Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 solid solution, while at mean time part of Zr4+ions dissociate from Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 and precipitate to form ZrO2. For Pd/CZA2-a, cubic CeO2 phase and tetragonal ZrO2 phase still can retain after ageing. The existence of Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 solid solution also renders the wider operation window of Pd/CZA1-a compared to Pd/CZA2-a. As for Al2O3 species, both meta-stable θ-Al2O3 and stable α-Al2O3 are verified in Pd/CZA1-a due to phase transition of γ-Al2O3, while only θ-Al2O3 phase can be found on Pd/CZA2-a. Previous reports suggest that the formation of α-Al2O3 phase would cause drastic decrease of specific surface areas and the dissociated Zr4+ could effectively hinder the θ-Al2O3 to α-Al2O3 phase transition [22,23]. Thus, the tetragonal ZrO2 phase in the fresh Pd/CZA-2 can provide abundant dissociated Zr4+ions and thus exhibiting less severe loss of specific surface area (see the smaller ΔSBET of Pd/CZA-2 in Table 1 above). Moreover, the crystalline size of Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 in Pd/CZA1-a remains quite small, which might be explained as the formation of α-Al2O3 leads to embedment of Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 particles. Such embedment phenomenon on one hand helps to suppress the agglomeration of Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 particles but on the hand also makes the PdOx species (strongly interacted with CeO2-ZrO2) very difficult to reduce (see the H2-TPR analysis section below), resulting in deteriorated catalytic performance. 3.3 Surface chemistry by XPS XPS characterizations were conducted to verify chemical state of surface elements. The recorded XPS profiles with multi-peak fitting are shown in Fig. 8 and the corresponding data are listed in Table 3 [24–26]. In the Pd 3d and Zr 3p spectra (Fig. 8A for fresh samples and Fig. 8B for aged samples), the fresh Pd/CZA-2 possesses higher metallic Pd° content than Pd/CZA-1. The metallic Pd0 is generally recognized as active sites for NO dissociation, therefore the fresh Pd/CZA-2 exhibits catalytic advantages for NO conversion [27,28]. After high temperature ageing, all the Pd species exist in the oxidized PdO state in Pd/CZA1-a and these high valent PdO species are beneficial for CO oxidation. The proportion of metallic Pd0 is quite low in both fresh and aged Pd/La-A, which explains its poor activity toward to NO conversion. In the Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 8C), two major sets of spin-orbit multiplex lines can be observed as u series and v series. Six characteristic peaks of Ce4+ can be identified as u (900.6∼901.0 eV), u'' (907.5∼907.7 eV), u''' (916.6∼916.9 eV), v (882.2∼882.6 eV) v'' (889.1∼889.3 eV) and v''' (898.2∼898.5.8 eV), while two characteristic peaks of Ce3+ can be identified as u' (903.5∼904.2 eV) and v' (885.1∼885.8 eV) [29–32]. The generation of Ce3+ species are generally associated with oxygen vacancies formation, therefore the ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) are calculated via peak area integration. For the fresh catalysts, Pd/CZA-1 shows higher Ce3+ content than Pd/CZA-2, which suggests its higher concentration of oxygen vacancies and is beneficial for wider operational window. After high temperature ageing, the Ce3+ content of Pd/CZA1-a decreases from 29.7% to 27.9% while for Pd/CZA2-a Ce3+ content increases from 22.1% to 25.6%, possibly originated from atomic migration or rearrangement at high temperature [33]. Pd/CZA1-a possesses higher Ce3+ content than Pd/CZA2-a, resulting in its wider operational window than Pd/CZA2-a after thermal ageing. 3.4 Redox properties by H2-TPR Fig. 9 A presents the H2-TPR profiles of all the prepared catalysts. For the fresh catalysts, one or two major reduction peaks appear in the testing temperature range. The low temperature peak under 60 °C (peak α) is attributed to the reduction of PdOx dispersed on the catalysts surface, while the reduction peak around 100 oC to 150 oC (peak β) is attributed to the reduction of PdOx species strongly interacted with CeO2-ZrO2 support [34–36]. By calculating the hydrogen consumption value, we can see that the hydrogen consumption belonging to β peak in Pd/CZA-1 (474 μmol/gcat) is much higher than the theoretical value of PdOx reduction (94 μmol/gcat). This is generally attributed to the promoted as reduction of interfacial Ce4+ at relatively low temperature due to the hydrogen spill-over effect induced by strong interaction between PdOx and CeO2-ZrO2 support [32,37]. For Pd/CZA-2, the total hydrogen consumption (peak “α+β”) is quite low (143 μmol/gcat), indicating the relatively weakened interaction between PdOx and CeO2-ZrO2. For Pd/La-A, no hydrogen spill-over can be observed as Al2O3 is considered to be inert support which is difficult to undergo electronic interaction with precious metal. The hydrogen consumption belonging to peak α in Pd/La-A is pretty close to the theoretical value. Besides, a negative reduction peak around 70 oC can be clearly seen, which is assigned to the decomposition peak of metal hydride PdHx species [35,38]. Based on previous studies, such metal hydride PdHx is more likely to form over large Pd particles [39–41]. Therefore, the negative reduction peak also proves that Al2O3 support was not able to stabilize noble metals in highly dispersed state due to lack of metal-support interaction. Fig. 9B presents the H2-TPR profiles of all the aged catalysts. For Pd/CZA1-a, peak α emerges after thermal ageing and peak β shifts to higher temperature. These changes indicate the possible embedment of PdOx species caused by CeO2-ZrO2 sintering and aggregation. Combing the specific surface area results (drastically decreased SBET in Pd/CZA1-a), we may assume that such embedment phenomenon is relatively severe and is very likely to cause surface active sites loss. Therefore, the catalytic conversion activity of HC and NO over Pd/CZA1-a significantly decreases after the high temperature aging. For Pd/CZA2-a, no obvious shifting of peak β is observed and the hydrogen consumption increases from 69 μmol/gcat to 108 μmol/gcat after thermal ageing, which could be related to migration of Pd species from Al2O3 particles to CeO2-ZrO2 particles and are thereby stabilized by the metal-support interaction. Moreover, the negative reduction peaks representing the PdHx species appear in all the three aged catalysts, suggesting the existence of sintered Pd particles [42]. The PdHx peak intensity follows the order of Pd/La-A-a > Pd/CZA1-a > Pd/CZA2-a, demonstrating the Pd species on Pd/CZA2-a presented relatively small particle size, which explains why Pd/CZA2-a shows greatly higher catalytic activity for HC and NO conversion after thermal ageing. 3.5 Stability and structural properties of Pd species by O2-TPSR and CO IR The stability of PdOx species significantly affects the TWC catalytic performance and therefore series of O2-TPSR tests were conducted to study the stability of PdOx species dispersed on CZA and La-A supports in oxidizing atmosphere. Fig. 10 presents the O2-TPSR results for both fresh and aged catalysts. The obvious negative peak appears during temperature ramping is attributed to the decomposition of PdOx species while the positive peak appears during cooling period is assigned to the reoxidation of metallic Pd [43,44]. For the fresh catalyst, the PdOx decomposition temperature of Pd/CZA-1 (933 oC) is higher than that of Pd/CZA-2 (857oC) and Pd/La-A (874 oC), indicating better thermal stability of PdOx species on Pd/CZA-1due to strong metal-support interaction. On the other hand, the Pd reoxidation temperature of Pd/La-A (57 oC) is much lower than that of Pd/CZA-1 (683oC) and Pd/CZA-2 (694 oC), which is also reasonable attributed to the lack of metal-support interaction between Pd and Al2O3. The reoxidation ratio of Pd is also quantitatively calculated and listed in Table 3. We can see that Pd/CZA-1 (40%) presents much higher Pd reoxidation ratio than Pd/CZA-2 (28.3%) and Pd/La-A (25.0%). Such higher Pd reoxidation ratio demonstrates that PdOx species in fresh Pd/CZA-1 is majorly dispersed on CeO2-ZrO2 surface, and the strong interaction between PdOx and CeO2-ZrO2 can improve the reoxidation ability of metallic Pd so that PdOx species could maintain higher oxidation state in the reaction atmosphere, thus being beneficial for HC oxidation. These results agree well with H2-TPR, XPS as well as activity test results. After high temperature ageing, both PdOx and support materials suffer severe sintering with particle size growth, and the metal-support interaction is also weakened. Therefore, the PdOx decomposition peaks shift to the low-temperature on all the aged catalysts, especially on Pd/CZA1-a, which might be related to the severe sintering of its Al2O3 phase. Besides, we can see from Fig. 10B that the PdOx decomposition temperature of Pd/CZA2-a remains around 853 oC, while that of Pd/CZA1-a and Pd/La-A-a drops to 805 oC and 806 oC, respectively. According to previous literatures, the interaction between CeO2-ZrO2 and Al2O3 can enhance the stability of PdOx as well as the reoxidation ability of metallic Pd. In Pd/CZA2-a, such interaction between CeO2-ZrO2 and Al2O3 can be preserved even after high temperature ageing, since the γ-Al2O3 in Pd/CZA2-a did not transform to α-Al2O3 owing to the stabilizing effect of ZrO2 (see the textural and structural characterization results above). Therefore, the PdOx species on Pd/CZA2-a has relatively higher stability compared with Pd/CZA1-a. As for Pd/La-A, lowest reoxidation ratio of metallic Pd before and after aging can be expected and verified due to lack of metal-support interaction. The structural properties of Pd species were further investigated by CO IR and the recorded spectra are shown in Fig. 11 . The IR peaks at 2092 cm−1, 1695 cm−1 and 1926 cm−1 are assigned to CO adsorption on metallic Pd at atop form (CO-Pd0), bridge-bonded (CO-2Pd0) form and three-fold hollow (CO-3Pd0) form, respectively, which is related to the size of the Pd cluster [45–47]. For the fresh catalysts, the CO-Pd0 atop form appears to be the dominant adsorption form, and the corresponding adsorption peak area follows the order as Pd/CZA-1 > Pd/CZA-2 > Pd/La-A. This suggests that the dispersion of PdOx species in Pd/CZA-1 is relatively high, generating more (Pd)n clusters with smaller particle size, rendering Pd/CZA-1 better catalytic activity. Pd/La-A shows the lowest Pd dispersion despite its large specific surface areas (also evidenced by the PdHx decomposition peak in H2-TPR above), which leads to decrease in active sites and inferior catalytic activity. Pd/CZA-2 shows larger amount of CO-2Pd0 and CO-3Pd0 adsorption species than Pd/CZA-1, indicating higher proportion of (Pd)n clusters with large particle size in Pd/CZA-2. NO reduction reaction is reported to be structure-sensitive with NO bond cleavage as the rate-determining step [48]. (Pd)n clusters with large particle size are considered more favorable for breaking NO bond, therefore Pd/CZA-2 exhibits a better performance for NO reduction. After high temperature ageing, the number of adsorption species in all these three forms is significantly decreased, due to the severe sintering of both PdOx species and the support materials. But in the overall trends, Pd/CZA2-a still remains relatively large CO adsorption peak area, namely the Pd species shows relatively good high-temperature thermal stability, which is consistent with above H2-TPR analyses. 3.6 In situ DRFITS analyses To gain further insight into the reaction intermediates evolution and possible structure-activity relationship for the prepared Pd/CZA and Pd/La-A catalysts during TWC reaction, in situ DRIFTS study was performed under stimulated reaction atmosphere with temperature ranging from 50 °C to 400 °C. As can be seen from Fig. 12 , for the fresh catalyst, the IR bands at 1305 cm−1,1435 cm−1,1548 cm−1,1613 cm−1 at low temperature ranges are assigned to nitrates species adsorbed on the catalyst surface [49,50]. As temperature increasing above 250 °C, the adsorption peak of carbonate/acetate species increases (1350–1500 cm −1), accompanied by the decomposition of nitrate species [51,52]. Meanwhile, NO adsorption on metallic Pd0 (IR band at 1736 cm−1) can be observed on the Pd/CZA-1 catalyst, but this NO-Pd0 peak iss not seen on Pd/La-A, explaining why Pd/CZA-1 shows better NO conversion ability [45,53,54]. The IR bands located at ca. 2985 cm−1 and 2972 cm−1 are related to the stretching vibration of CH bonds, which increases significantly with temperature ramping and then decreases sharply on the Pd/CZA-1 catalyst, indicating that hydrocarbons underwent rapid adsorption first followed by rapid conversion and desorption over Pd/CZA-1 [55]. However, for Pd/La-A, these adsorbed hydrocarbons peaks not only increase quite slowly but also disappears really gradually with temperature heating up (strong peak intensity even at 370 °C). Therefore, the HC conversion activity of Pd/La-A significantly worse than Pd/CZA-1. Some researchers have pointed out that the strong adsorption of HC on the Pd/La-A surface could lead to poisoning and deactivation of the active sites, causing inhibition of NO reduction [56]. This can also explain why Pd/La-A could not achieve complete NO conversion even at high temperature during TWC activity test. Fig. 13 shows the in-situ DRIFTS spectra of Pd/CZA2-a and Pd/La-A-a after high temperature aging. It can be seen that the HC adsorption peak begins to appear on Pd/CZA2-a around 210 °C, with peak intensity first increases and then decreases upon arising the reaction temperature; while on Pd/La-Aa, the HC adsorption peak only start to appear at high temperature above 350 °C. At the same time, the adsorbed nitrate species (1230 cm−1) decompose at 290 °C on Pd/CZA2-a, while these nitrate species have been stable at higher reaction temperature on Pd/La-A-a, supporting the NO conversion advantages on Pd/CZA2-a than Pd/La-A-a. In addition, the adsorption of carbonate/acetate species (1350–1500 cm−1) on the two catalysts are also very different. We can see that the adsorption peak of carbonate species on Pd/CZA2-a are obviously stronger, but they are almost undetectable on Pd/La-A-a, further confirming that Pd/CZA2-a is more beneficial for HC and CO oxidation. 4 Conclusions Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 with different pore structures were synthesized for comparison with lanthanum modified Pd/La-Al2O3. TWC activity tests as well as detailed characterizations were conducted to explore the effect of CeO2-ZrO2 modification on catalytic behavior, thermal stability as well as structure-activity correlations. The obtained results demonstrate that: First of all, Pd/CZA catalysts show significant TWC activity advantages over Pd/La-A catalyst due to the strong interaction between PdOx species and CeO2-ZrO2 support, which can stabilize PdOx in high dispersion states with small particle size. While the lack of such meta-support interaction in Pd/La-A causes inferior catalytic behavior regardless of thermal ageing. Secondly, the thermal stability of Pd/CZA catalysts is related to their different microstructure. Pd/CZA-1 presents superior TWC activity with wide operating window, but the formation of α-Al2O3 phase during ageing causes serious embedment of CeO2-ZrO2 and inhibits PdOx reduction. Fresh Pd/CZA-2 shows narrower operating window due to ZrO2 phase separation and lower oxygen vacancies content, but its abundant dissociated Zr4+ could hinder the θ-Al2O3 to α-Al2O3 phase transition and retain small-sized PdOx species with excellent reoxidation ability, thus rendering Pd/CZA-2 better thermal stability. Moreover, obvious structure-activity correlations between the adsorbed reaction intermediates and TWC catalytic performance can be revealed. The fresh Pd/CZA-1 catalyst is conducive for NO conversion due to formation of NO-Pd0 species. The rapid adsorption/decomposition of HC and carbonate species make Pd/CZA beneficial for HC/CO oxidation. While the active sites poisoning by HC strong adsorption along with temperature-stable nitrate species on Pd/La-A-a lead to its poor TWC performance after thermal ageing. coredata.dc:description: Series of Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 (Pd/CZA) with different pore structures and lanthanum modified Pd/La-Al2O3 (Pd/La-A) were prepared via coprecipitation or hydrothermal method. The obtained catalysts were subjected to TWC activity evaluation, thermal stability tests as well as systematic characterizations including TEM, BET, Rietveld XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, O2-TPSR, and in situ DRIFTS. Results show that the TWC catalytic performance of Pd/Al2O3 catalyst can be obviously improved by CeO2-ZrO2 modification compared to La2O3 modification, due to the strong interaction between PdOx species and CeO2-ZrO2 support. The excellent thermal stability of Pd/CZA-2 catalyst is related to its different microstructure compared to Pd/CZA-1, because the abundant dissociated Zr4+ due to phase separation in Pd/CZA-2 could hinder the θ-Al2O3 to α-Al2O3 phase transition and retain small-sized PdOx species with excellent reoxidation ability. Besides, DRIFTS studies reveal clear structure-activity correlations between the adsorbed reaction intermediates and TWC catalytic performance, i.e. The formation of NO-Pd0 species on fresh Pd/CZA-1 is beneficial for NO conversion, while the rapid adsorption/decomposition of HC and carbonate species on Pd/CZA also contributes to better HC/CO oxidation. Nevertheless, the active sites poisoning by HC strong adsorption along with temperature-stable nitrate species on Pd/La-A cost its inferior catalytic behaviour regardless of thermal ageing.
coredata.dc:title: Comparative study of three-way catalytic performance over Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 and Pd/La-Al2O3 catalysts: New insights into microstructure and thermal stability
